@DavidPeicho WebGL 2.0 initial support has been merged. Do you want to make 3D texture support PR? https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/pull/13701#issuecomment-378418184
@mrdoob OK I'll make a PR for `isWebGL2` in `WebGLUtils`.

I have been using the Texture 3D with three.js for several months for now, so I imagine I can rebase my changes on yours yes.

The only thing is that I added the `internalFormat` directly inside the `Texture` object. As I did not want to break the API, I only added the attribute and I use it like that:

```javascript
const myTexture = new Texture3D(...);
myTexture.internalFormat = ...;
```

I saw that you automatically deduce the internalFormat, which is nice. I am just wondering if it will be the best in every scenarios.

@DavidPeicho

Sorry for the late response. 3D texture support PR has been made #14530. Is that same as how you were gonna implement? I'm very happy if you work with him there.
Quite close yes. I followed exactly the pattern that was already existing (`uploadTexture`, `uploadTexture3D`). But the PR #14530 looks good!

I am trying to understand the extent of this new WebGL2 support in three.js.  Specifically does this change allow me to utilize some of the additional texture formats supported in WebGL2 such as the R16UI and R16I texture formats ... and if so how?
We haven't supported new texture formats yet. I'm thinking to make WebGL2 new texture format support PR soon.

@twilson7755  I'd presume that the R16UI and R16I textures are used for some custom computation, right?  What I use the new texture types for is general purpose computation, and the way I do it is to get the WebGL2RenderingContext object, call createTexture() and texImage2D and keep the texture in my data structure.  I even create my shader programs in my data structure, and actually to have different types framebuffer, create such framebuffers, too. Then, by using .onBeforeRender or onAfterRender to trigger my computation (but make sure things are properly restored to the state that three.js assumes.)

If what you need is to pass in those as extra textures and shader code that that uses those, I'd presume that you don't necessarily keep all separate data, but with those shader code rewriting and stuff makes me stay away from trying to adapt it.

An example of all of this is available in a branch of my fork:

https://github.com/yoshikiohshima/three.js/tree/yoshiki
